place_of_publication.publication_title: Trudy Bot. Inst. Akad. Nauk S.S.S.R., Ser.

taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Greek pseudo -, deceptively similar, and genus name Gnaphalium , alluding to resemblance]

bio:treatment.discussion: Fifteen of the species treated here occur also in Mexico; those that do not are Pseudognaphalium obtusifolium, P. saxicola, P. micradenium, and P. helleri (eastern United States and adjacent Canada), and P. ramosissimum and P. thermale (western United States and adjacent Canada).

Basal and proximal leaves of Pseudognaphalium species often wither before plants reach flowering. In the key and descriptions here, references to leaves are to cauline leaves of plants at flowering unless otherwise indicated.

references.reference: Nesom, G. L. 2004d. Pseudognaphalium canescens (Asteraceae: Gnaphalieae) and putative relatives in western North America. Sida 21: 781–790.

key_statement.description: Leaf faces strongly to weakly bicolor (abaxial gray to white, tomentose, adaxial green, not tomentose, sometimes glandular).
Bases of leaf blades not clasping, not decurrent.
Stems white (tomentose, rarely glandular near bases); pistillate florets 38–96; bisexual florets 4–8(–11)
Stems greenish (lacking or soon losing most tomentum, usually densely stipitate-glandular); pistillate florets 47–107; bisexual florets 7–20.

Stems glandular-villous (stipitate glands mostly 0.3–1 mm, variable in height on any portion of stem, stalks broadened toward bases, about equaling gland widths); leaf blades mostly oblong-lanceolate, 2.5–7 cm × 4–20 mm; pistillate

Stems glandular-puberulent (stipitate glands 0.1–0.2 mm, stalks narrower than gland widths); leaf blades linear to linear-lanceolate or linear-oblanceolate, 1.5–5.5 cm × 1.5–10 mm; pistillate florets 47–78; bisexual florets (7–)11–20
Bases of leaf blades clasping and/or decurrent.
Leaves crowded (internodes usually 1–3, sometimes to 10 mm), blades linear to linear-lanceolate, margins strongly revolute.
Phyllaries bright white, opaque, dull; cypselar faces smooth
Phyllaries tawny to silvery white, ± hyaline, shiny; cypselar faces papillate-roughened.

Stems stipitate-glandular; leaf bases not subclasping (proximal usually decurrent 3–10 mm); phyllaries ovate-lanceolate (apices of inner not thickened along midribs, not apiculate); pistillate florets ca. 200–250; bisexual florets (13–)16–29

Stems not glandular; leaf bases subclasping (not decurrent); phyllaries narrowly ovate to oblong or elliptic (apices of inner thickened and slightly raised along midribs, apiculate); pistillate florets [46–]76–102; bisexual florets (6–)8–11
Leaves not crowded (internodes mostly more than 5 mm), blades elliptic, elliptic-ovate, lanceolate, oblanceolate, or oblong, margins flat or slightly revolute.
Stems not glandular; leaf bases auriculate-clasping, faces strongly bicolor
Stems glandular; leaf bases weakly, if at all, clasping, faces strongly to weakly bicolor.
Involucres 4.5–5.5 mm; phyllaries in 4–5 series; bisexual florets 7–12
Involucres 3.5–4 mm; phyllaries in 2–3 series; bisexual florets (1–)2–6
Leaf faces concolor or weakly bicolor (both usually gray to gray-green or greenish, tomentose, adaxial sometimes glandular beneath tomentum).
Leaf bases clasping to subclasping, seldom decurrent (decurrent 1–2 mm in P. luteoalbum and P. stramineum , 2–10 mm in P. californicum ).

Heads in terminal glomerules; involucres 3–6 mm; phyllaries silver-gray to yellowish (hyaline); pistillate florets 135–160 (pappus bristles loosely coherent basally, released in clusters or easily fragmented rings).
Involucres 3–4 mm; bisexual florets 5–10 (corollas red-tipped; cypselae with papilliform hairs)
Involucres 4–6 mm; bisexual florets mostly 18–28 (corollas evenly yellowish, not red-tipped; cypselae glabrous)

Heads in corymbiform arrays; involucres 4–7 mm; phyllaries usually silvery white to white, sometimes pink (mostly opaque); pistillate florets 35–140 (pappus bristles not coherent basally, released singly).
Stems stipitate-glandular; abaxial faces of leaf blades green, stipitate- glandular; phyllaries in 7–10 series
Stems not glandular; abaxial faces of leaf blades white-tomentose or woolly- tomentose; phyllaries in 5–6 series
Leaf bases not clasping or subclasping, decurrent or not.
Leaf bases not decurrent.
Annuals 4–15(–30) cm; faces of leaf blades concolor, green, thinly arachnoid-tomentose to glabrate, not glandular (veiny reticulum evident); heads in terminal capitate clusters; cypselae smooth

Annuals, biennials, or perennials, 20–100+ cm; faces of leaf blades concolor or weakly bicolor, white to gray, ± tomentose, sometimes glandular beneath tomentum; heads in corymbiform arrays; cypselae smooth or papillate-roughened.
Adaxial faces of leaf blades sometimes sessile-glandular beneath adaxial tomentum; involucres 4–5 mm; phyllaries in 3–4 series; bisexual florets (1–)2–
Adaxial faces of leaf blades not glandular; involucres 5–6 mm; phyllaries in 4–6 series; bisexual florets 5–9
Leaf bases decurrent.
Stems and leaves stipitate-glandular; heads in corymbiform or paniculiform arrays; phyllaries usually white or pinkish, sometimes greenish.
Leaf blades mostly narrowly oblong-lanceolate, 5–10(–20) mm wide; heads in corymbiform arrays; involucres campanulo-globose; phyllaries in 7–10 series, white

Leaf blades linear to lanceolate, oblong, or narrowly spatulate, 3–5(–7) mm wide; heads in paniculiform (usually elongate to broadly columnar) arrays; involucres turbinate to short-cylindric; phyllaries in 4–5 series, usually pinkish, sometimes white to greenish

Stems and leaves not glandular; heads usually in corymbiform or paniculiform arrays (sometimes borne singly or in glomerules in P. arizonicum ); phyllaries usually white, whitish, or brownish to tawny, rarely rosy.
Phyllaries usually brownish to tawny, rarely rosy, ovate-lanceolate to lanceolate (hairs of stems and leaves commonly with reddish or purplish cross walls)
Phyllaries white or whitish, ovate to ovate-oblong (hairs of stems and leaves without colored cross walls).
Pistillate florets 80–115[–180]; bisexual florets (6–)8–12[–30] (bases of hairs on leaves persistent, enlarged)
Pistillate florets 35–69; bisexual florets 3–8(–11) (bases of hairs on leaves not persistent and enlarged).

Blades of basal and proximal cauline leaves linear (proximal and distal similar in size and shape); heads usually in paniculiform arrays; phyllaries in (4–)5–6(–7) series (usually opaque, dull to shiny)

Blades of basal and proximal cauline leaves linear-oblanceolate (the distal shorter and narrower); heads in corymbiform to paniculiform arrays; phyllaries in 3–4(–5) series, hyaline or opaque, usually shiny, sometimes dull
